item.title: Algorithmically, I thought I should know Peel Dream Magazine by now. Their‚Ä¶
item.description:
Algorithmically, I thought I should know Peel Dream Magazine by now. Their music has been compared to some of my personal favorites Broadcast, Stereolab, and Yo La Tengo. The ‚ÄúPeel‚Äù in their name is a dedication to the late BBC Radio1 deejay John Peel. I‚Äôm just old enough that the phrase ‚ÄúPeel Session‚Äù means something to me. They are on a favorite label, Top Shelf Records (I‚Äôm in the¬†Discord).

Ah well. I found my way to this music via the SimpleBits Studio Notes newsletter. Dan writes he heard them on SiriusXM. Long live the radio and the personal recommendation.

Rose Main Reading Room is a great name for a concept album about New York City and its landmarks. This is a ‚Äúheadphones record‚Äù; baroque pop meets Y2K dream pop sounds. I love everything I‚Äôve heard so far, and my ears are hungry for¬†more.

Also posted to Crucial Tracks.

item.title: Why I Don't Need a Steam Machine
item.dc:creator: Wouter Groeneveld
item.description:
For those of you who are living under a rock, Valve announced three new hardware devices joining their Steam Deck line-up: a new controller, a VR headset, and the GameCube‚Äîno wait, GabeCube‚Äîno wait, Steam Machine. The shiny little cube is undoubtedly Valve‚Äôs (second) attempt to break into the console market. This time, it might just work.

The hardware is ready to arrive in at your living room spring next year. The biggest question is: will it arrive at our living room? Reading all the hype has certainly enthused me (e.g. Brendon‚Äôs The Steam Machine is the Future, PC Gamer‚Äôs Valve is all over ARM, Eurogamer‚Äôs Steam Machine preview, ResetEra‚Äôs Steam Hardware thread); especially the part where the Machine is just a PC that happens to be tailored towards console gaming. According to Valve, you can install anything you want on it‚Äîit‚Äôs just SteamOS just like your trusty Deck, meaning you can boot into KDE and totally do your thing. Except that this shiny little cube is six times as powerful. I‚Äôm sure Digital Foundry will validate that next year.

However, this post isn‚Äôt about specs, expectations, or dreams: it‚Äôs about tempering my own enthusiasm. I‚Äôd like to tell myself why I don‚Äôt really need a Steam Machine. The following list will hopefully make it easier to say no when the buy buttons become available.

  • You‚Äôre a retro gamer.
    You don‚Äôt need the power of six Steam Decks. To do what, run DOSBox?
  • Your TV doesn‚Äôt support 4K.
    Again, no need for those 4K 60 FPS.
  • You generally dislike AAA games.
    With The Steam Machine, you might be able to finally properly run DOOM Eternal and all of the Assassin‚Äôs Creed games. That you don‚Äôt like playing.
  • You don‚Äôt have time to play games anyway.
    Ouch, that hurts but it‚Äôs not untrue.
  • The TV will be occupied anyway.
    The Steam Machine is not a Switch: you can‚Äôt switch to handheld mode. When are you going to play on the Machine if the TV is being used to watch your wife‚Äôs favourite shows?
  • You already have too many gaming related hardware pieces.
    That‚Äôll mean you‚Äôll have to divide your time by an even bigger number to devote an equal amount to playing them.
  • There‚Äôs no room for yet another nondescript box under the TV.
    See above: why don‚Äôt you first try to do something with that SNES Mini and PlayStation Mini besides letting it collect dust?
  • You‚Äôre a physical gamer.
    This is Steam. There will be no insertion of cartridges, no blowing of carts, and no staring at game collections on a shelf.
  • It‚Äôs Steam, not Good Old Games.
    Sure it can run GOG games but the Machine is primarily designed to run Steam. You avoid purchasing from Steam like the plague, yet you‚Äôre willing to buy a Machine dedicated to it? Are you crazy?
  • The last time you booted Steam was over a year ago.
    Don‚Äôt tell me you‚Äôre suddenly interested in running the platform on a dedicated machine.
  • You don‚Äôt have time to fiddle with configuration.
    Button and trackpad mappings to get the controls just right enough to play strategy games designed to be played with keyboard and mouse will only leave you frustrated.
  • Your MacBook can emulate Windows games just fine.
    You recently bought CrossOver and played Wizordum and older Windows 98/XP stuff on it. It even runs Against The Storm flawlessly. No need for Proton or whatever.
  • In two years, you‚Äôll upgrade your M1 to an M4+: there‚Äôs the power upgrade.
    If CrossOver is struggling to run that particular game you so badly want to play, it‚Äôll be buttery smooth in a few years. You‚Äôre going to do the laptop upgrade anyway regardless of the Steam Machine.
  • You already have a huge gaming backlog.
    Thanks to your buddy Joel you bought too many physical Switch games that are still waiting to be touched. Are you really ready to open up another can of worms?
  • You dislike a digital backlog.
    It‚Äôs easy to have hundreds of games on there: see your GOG purchases. Why don‚Äôt you try to count the ones that you actually played, let alone finished.
  • You‚Äôre not going to use the Machine to run office software.
    Your laptop and other retro machines are good enough at handling that task. What are you really going to do with this cube besides gaming?
  • Those cool looking indie games will be released for Switch in due time anyway.
    Remember Pizza Tower? It‚Äôs out on Switch now. Remember to buy the cart on Fangamer, together with the Anton Blast one.
  • It‚Äôs rumoured to cost more than ‚Ç¨600.
    Save that money for a Switch 2 if the games are starting to become interesting to justify that upgrade, as currently, they‚Äôre not. Also, see the backlog point above.
  • All HDMI ports both on the TV and your external monitors are occupied.
    Unless you‚Äôre willing to constantly switch cables, you‚Äôll need to invest in a HDMI switch. Another ‚Ç¨100+.
  • You can‚Äôt buy this without buying the Steam Controller.
    That‚Äôs easily another ‚Ç¨80+ you already spent buying the Mobapad controller for your Switch as a replacement for the semi-broken Joy Cons.
  • You can‚Äôt buy this as an expense on the company.
    You‚Äôre closing down the company, remember. (More on that later)
  • The cool looking LED and programmable front display don‚Äôt justify an expensive purchase.
    After the initial excitement wears off, the LED will become annoying and you‚Äôll simply turn it off.

So you see, I don‚Äôt really need a Steam Machine‚Ä¶

Fuck it, I‚Äôm getting one.

Related topics: / steam / games /

By Wouter Groeneveld on 16 November 2025.¬† Reply via email.

item.title: Another video of Canadian youths biking unwisely
item.dc:creator: lauram
item.description:
I posted another video from this channel previously - a video where two Canadians (possibly college students??) made a bikepacking rig out of stuff they bought and taped together from the hardware store. I appreciated their deranged commitment to the low-cost bit.

I have to also recommend this video of them going bikepacking without any food... and eating out of trash cans and animals they grab out of the ocean with their hands.

You will have to watch the video to learn which animal they eat out of the ocean:

item.title: Confessions of a Charm School Dropout
item.dc:creator: Musings from a Tangled Mind
item.description:
It‚Äôs funny that today‚Äôs writing prompt is, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the first impression I want to give people?‚Äù Because I swear the universe is messing with me ‚Äî this exact topic blindsided me yesterday while I was shopping with a friend. I was minding my business, smelling a candle, and she just hits me with, ‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶ what vibe do you think you give off to strangers?‚Äù

I just stared at her. I mean‚Ä¶ what? Why are we doing interview questions in Aisle 3? I thought we were just trying to find the bathroom in Target.

And she clearly expected me to say something inspirational like, ‚ÄúI hope people see my inner glow,‚Äù or ‚ÄúI try to radiate compassion.‚Äù No. I don‚Äôt glow. I don‚Äôt radiate. At best, I mildly hum, but more in a ‚Äúshe‚Äôs getting ready to explode‚Äù kind of a way‚Ä¶ you know, like Perfection right before it detonates.

Then, before I can even stop spluttering long enough to formulate a socially acceptable answer, she shrugged and went, ‚ÄúWelp‚Ä¶ whatever the answer is, that‚Äôs not the face you‚Äôre giving off.‚Äù What the hell, Brenda?

Then I narrowed my eyes and asked, ‚ÄúDoes this have anything to do with that old man in the seasonal section? He startled me. You saw it. There were gourds, Brenda.‚Äù

Look, I know I should probably make a better first impression. But I‚Äôm also self-aware enough to know that I absolutely don‚Äôt. At best, I give off a general aura of, ‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre lovely, but maybe‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt talk to me?‚Äù

The thing is, I don‚Äôt have resting bitch face. This is literally just my face. This is the factory default. This is what it looks like when I‚Äôm standing still.

People assume I‚Äôm mad, but no. I‚Äôm probably thinking about pasta. Or trying to remember whether I left laundry in the washer in 2014. I‚Äôve got a whole inner world happening here that has absolutely nothing to do with anyone around me, and it‚Äôs hard to convey that without making things worse.

And then there‚Äôs the smiling thing. I forget to do it. Unless I‚Äôm laughing at something in my own head (because I‚Äôm a delight) or there‚Äôs a baby or an animal involved, it just doesn‚Äôt occur to me.

There is always ‚Äî ALWAYS ‚Äî some overly cheerful human who hits me with the ‚ÄúYou should smile more!‚Äù Ma‚Äôam. Sir. Please. If you saw my intentional smile, you would take that back immediately.

You know how a dog looks when someone teaches it to ‚Äúsmile?‚Äù That stiff, awkward teethy ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing this for a treat and I hate every moment‚Äù grimace? That‚Äôs exactly what I look like when I force a smile. Nobody needs that energy aimed at them in a grocery store. It‚Äôs very ‚ÄúI swear I‚Äôm normal, please don‚Äôt call security.‚Äù

The point is, while other people are out here trying to give off approachable, bubbly, sunshine-on-a-stick energy, I am‚Ä¶ not. I‚Äôm aiming more for ‚Äúfriendly raccoon that might run away if you make eye contact.‚Äù But also, I might bite. It‚Äôs hard to say.

I‚Äôm not unfriendly. I‚Äôm just‚Ä¶ cautious. Socially allergic. Pick your adjective. I don‚Äôt care what you call me so long as you don‚Äôt call me.

So what first impression do I WANT to give? I want to look like someone who is perfectly nice once you know me but maybe doesn‚Äôt need to be spoken to immediately upon entry. I want to give off ‚ÄúGive me a minute‚Äù energy. Sometimes several minutes. Sometimes days. It depends on how early in the morning it is.

In short, I would very much like to be left alone.
Respectfully.
Gently.
The way you‚Äôd leave a sleeping cat alone even though it looks cute and you want to pet it.

And if you catch me looking like I‚Äôm judging you, I promise I‚Äôm not. My face is just buffering. But also‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt feel pressured to talk to me while it loads.

.

item.title: How Many Posts Is Too Many?
item.description:
I have been publishing a new post every day since mid September. I‚Äôve had a good time doing it, and I‚Äôm going to continue on into next year unless something happens. But I do have to wonder, does publishing too much bug those of you who subscribe to my RSS feed? Do the people who post four or five times a day, usually short posts, come across as spammy? Is there such a thing as too many posts?

The other day, I published three in one day. Now it was a link and a video along with a regular post, but there was still a voice in the back of my head that asked if it was too much. I subscribe to a few bloggers who use their blogs as more of a daily note type thing, which means they post many times a day. It doesn‚Äôt really bother me, but I don‚Äôt read all of their posts. Maybe that‚Äôs the expectation, so nothing is really wrong here. But it is something I think about as I continue to work towards my 200th post this year.

item.title: Walk with me: On my soapbox
item.description:
I hope you‚Äôll enjoy this stream-of-consciousness reflection on the last crazy year as I prepare for 2026. Apologies for the lack of a write-up, I am crunched for time at the moment. I hope this before and after makes up for it!

Thank you for reading this through RSS üì°

Your thoughts and feedback are both very important to me.
Get in touch!
